item.title: Can a heated mirror still reflect?
item.description: A science experiment tests whether heating a mirror changes its ability to reflect light, exploring what really happens at the surface when temperature increases.

media:content.media:title: Can a heated mirror still reflect?
media:content.media:description: A science experiment tests whether heating a mirror changes its ability to reflect light, exploring what really happens at the surface when temperature increases.

item.title: The world’s fastest heat conductor
item.description: A science experiment tests an extremely fast heat conductor, showing how quickly thermal energy can move through certain materials and why it behaves this way.

item.title: I broke this engine!
item.description: A science experiment pushes an engine past its limits, breaking it down to explain the physics behind what went wrong and how the failure happened.

item.title: When a rubber hand starts to feel real
item.description: A classic science experiment demonstrates how the brain can be tricked into accepting a fake hand as part of the body, revealing the surprising power of perception and illusion.

item.title: The physics question most people get wrong
item.description: A hands-on physics experiment challenges a common misconception, using a balloon and a drone to reveal what really happens according to the laws of physics.

item.title: Is it possible to live in 2D instead of 3D?
item.description: A thought-provoking science experiment explores what life would look like in two dimensions, using physics to explain why our world is fundamentally three-dimensional.

item.title: Smart magnets
item.description: An experiment explores how smart magnets behave, showing their unique interactions and the science behind their surprising movements and forces.

item.title: Is your phone cooking your brain?
item.description: A science-based look at whether smartphones can actually heat or harm your brain, examining radiation, energy levels, and what the research really shows.

item.title: How secret spy glasses really work
item.description: A closer look at so-called spy glasses, breaking down the science behind how they function and what they can and can’t actually do.

item.title: Skydiving with umbrellas?
item.description: An experiment explores whether umbrellas can actually slow a fall while skydiving, using science to test a long-standing myth.

item.title: The mystery of cold light explained
item.description: This experiment explores how certain light sources can glow brightly without producing heat, revealing the surprising science behind so-called “cold light.”

item.title: A perfectly balanced balloon
item.description: A simple science experiment shows how a balloon can be balanced in an unexpected way, demonstrating the principles of physics and stability.

item.title: Why chicken heads stay fixed while the body moves
item.description: Discover the surprising reflex that lets chickens keep their heads perfectly steady no matter how their bodies move.

item.title: How this powder works as a liquid thickener
item.description: A simple science demonstration showing how a special powder increases a liquid’s thickness by changing its surface area and flow behavior.

item.title: Why does sodium metal shrink?
item.description: I show you thermal expansion actually changing the length of a piece of sodium metal.

item.title: This is how surface tension works to hold water in a glass
item.description: I show you how water can be held in a glass with a screen and some water

item.title: Seeing quantum physics with razor blades
item.description: In this video I show you how to demonstrate the Uncertainty Principle with nothing more than a laser and razor blade

item.title: Examining the meteor that hit russia
item.description: The most valuable material isn’t from earth

item.title: Manipulating matter with light!
item.description: In this video I show you how to trap particles with focused light. I talk about light having momentum and how this experiment can hold particles in place using only light.

item.title: How a fan blade creates a laser beam
item.description: In this video I make a laser gun just like in star wars that shoots laser bullets that you can actually see.
